item.title: Enforce Safe Search on Google, YouTube, Bing
item.description: Enforce safe search on Google, YouTube, and Bing without a HTTP proxy. Instead, override DNS lookups, resolving to strict search server IP addresses. Works on IPv4 and IPv6 networks.

item.title: Hugo Static Site Generator with CI Deployment using GitLab
item.description: Over the weekend, I moved my blog from GitHub to GitLab. I now have a fully automated CI build on GitLab that grabs a NodeJS Docker image, downloads Hugo, UglifyCSS and HTMLMinifier via NPM, build and minify pages, and finally publishes to GitLab Pages on every Git merge to master.

item.title: GitHub, VSTS, Google Cloud folder icons
item.description: Set folder icons for your favourite source control repositories.

item.title: .NET Core on Google Cloud f1-micro instance
item.description: Given that .NET Core is capable of running on Linux, I decided to try running a simple Hello World test on Google Cloud Platform f1-micro instance and also ran OpenSSL speed tests.

item.title: .NET Core on Google App Engine
item.description: There is an easy tutorial on how to run .NET Core apps on Google Developers Codelabs. As a supplement to that I have some bits to share that may be of use to you.

item.title: Static blog generated by Hugo hosted on Google Firebase
item.description: I have migrated my blog from WordPress to static website generated by Hugo. Here is why.

item.title: Create Git repository on Google Drive/Dropbox
item.description: Setting up a single-user Git repository on privateÂ cloud storage is not difficult and incurs no cost to you.

item.title: Configuring OpenWRT and OpenDNS to log all DNS lookups
item.description:
Why log all DNS lookups?

  1. To list websites visited by you or any computer served by your router
  2. To assist in identifying presence of malware

item.title: OpenWRT redirect all NTP queries to specific servers
item.description: Most devices allow you to set the Network Time Protocol (NTP) server to one that you prefer but there are some devices that have hardcoded NTP server hostname. This is mostly fine if all devices in your local network are synchronised to the same second but this is not always true. I have seen NTP servers that drift over 30 seconds. Not good…
